conversation.content: Maya? Is that you?
[hushed disbelief] Don't say that name out loud, not here, not after all these years of being dead to everyone who knew me before.
[barely breathing] They told us you died in the warehouse fire twelve years ago, showed us the dental records and everything. [voice cracking] I mourned you for months.
[quietly urgent] The fire was real, the death wasn't—I had to disappear that night, and the bounty hunter identity kept me moving, kept me safe from the people who wanted me gone.
[trembling] You've been tracking me for three months, watching me from rooftops, following my subway routes, and you never once thought to just knock on my door?
[softly] I needed to know if you'd changed, if you'd become someone who'd turn me in for the reward money instead of the kid who used to share their lunch with me. [pause]
[wounded whisper] You actually thought I'd sell you out? After everything we went through together in foster care, all those nights planning our escape to become artists?
[quiet certainty] People change, Alex.
[leaning closer] Not that much. Never that much. You need something from me, don't you? That's why you finally revealed yourself tonight.

[exhales slowly] I need new identity documents, completely untraceable ones, and you're the only forger I trust who has the artistic skill to make them perfect. [quieter] The old ones are compromised.
[hushed realization] That's why you've been studying my work, memorizing my techniques—you weren't hunting me, you were vetting me for this job. The bounty was just cover.
[almost inaudible] The people who burned that warehouse are getting close again, and this time I need to disappear completely, become someone even you wouldn't recognize on the street.
[firmly] No. Absolutely not.
[whispered panic] Alex, please, I wouldn't ask if there was any other way—I've survived alone this long but they're closing in and I'm running out of moves.
I mean no to you disappearing again. [sighs] This time, we do it right—new identities for both of us, together, like we always planned.
[stunned whisper] You can't be serious. You have a life here, a studio, clients who depend on your work, everything we dreamed about when we were kids.
[soft but determined] I have a successful career built on forging other people's dreams into reality, but none of it means anything if my best friend is out there alone, running from ghosts.
[voice breaking] I can't ask you to give up everything you've built. [barely audible] I already took twelve years from you by letting you think I was dead.
[gently] You're not asking—I'm offering. Besides, my best work has always been collaborative, and we made a pretty good team back in the day. [quiet laugh]
[whispered hope] Two artists on the run sounds like a terrible plan, but then again, [soft exhale], we always did specialize in making the impossible look easy.
